title: Ticket #7462: Different token types should be distinguished in the cred dir
description:
NOTE: Documentation work to be done in ticket #7646

Currently, $(SEC_CREDENTIAL_DIRECTORY)/<username> could contain many different types of tokens, and we rely on the user and/or admin to know enough about the token storage configuration to avoid naming conflicts. I propose that we should distinguish the type of tokens by creating subdirectories either under $(SEC_CREDENTIAL_DIRECTORY) or <username>, e.g.: 

/var/lib/condor/credentials/jpatton/oauth/box.top
/var/lib/condor/credentials/jpatton/oauth/box.use
/var/lib/condor/credentials/jpatton/kerberos/krb5.cc
/var/lib/condor/credentials/jpatton/s3/chtc.access
/var/lib/condor/credentials/jpatton/s3/chtc.secret

Perhaps for getting multiple credmons to work nicely together, the distinguishing subdirectories should be up a level, with logs and such placed there instead of at the root of $(SEC_CREDENTIAL_DIRECTORY): 

/var/lib/condor/credentials/oauth/jpatton/box.top
/var/lib/condor/credentials/oauth/jpatton/box.use
/var/lib/condor/credentials/kerberos/jpatton/krb5.cc
/var/lib/condor/credentials/s3/jpatton/chtc.access
/var/lib/condor/credentials/s3/jpatton/chtc.secret

However, this means naming conflicts could still show up in the execute sandbox unless some care is taken by the starter to reorganize the sandbox's cred dir.

replace SEC_CREDENTIAL_DIRECTORY with multiple knobs

We will solve this problem, by switching the code to have more than one credential directory knob, there will be a separate knob for each credential directory namespace: password, krb, and oauth.

  • passwords will be stored in SEC_CREDENTIAL_DIRECTORY. The *nix builds do not normally store passwords other than the pool password, but this may change in the future. In any case the plumbing for this has always been in the code.

  • Kerberos credentials will be stored SEC_CREDENTIAL_DIRECTORY_KRB. It may be reasonable to default this to $(SEC_CREDENTIAL_DIRECTORY)/krb

  • OAuth tokens will be stored in SEC_CREDENTIAL_DIRECTORY_OAUTH. It may be reasonable to default this to $(SEC_CREDENTIAL_DIRECTORY)/oauth

Enable multiple instances of credmon

In the current code, the admin must add the credmon to the daemon list, we will need to have multiple instances of the credmon, so we will need to extend this mechanism to allow for multiple instances of the credmon, each managing a different credential directory. This will be handled by adding a daemon to the DAEMON_LIST for each credmon.

Schedd must block for multiple CREDMON_COMPLETE files

Since we may have multiple instances of the credmon, we will need multiple CREDMON_COMPLETE files. We will extending the existing pattern for this, such that each credmon directory will have it's own CREDMON_COMPLETE FILE.

If SEC_CREDENTIAL_DIRECTORY_KRB is configured, then the schedd will wait for a CREDMON_COMPLETE file to appear in this directory before it begins running jobs.

optional If SEC_CREDENTIAL_DIRECTORY_OAUTH is configured, then the schedd will wait for a CREDMON_COMPLETE file to appear in this directory before it begins running jobs.

THE Master will delete these files as part of it's startup processing.

configuring 

possible config fragment
DAEMON_LIST = $(DAEMON_LIST) CREDMON_KRB CREDMON_OAUTH

CREDMON_KRB = $(LIBEXEC)/credmon_krb
SEC_CREDENTIAL_DIRECTORY_KRB = $(SEC_CREDENTIAL_DIRECTORY)/krb
# The knob above will cause the Schedd to wait for $(SEC_CREDENTIAL_DIRECTORY_KRB)/CREDMON_COMPLETE

CREDMON_OAUTH = $(LIBEXEC)/credmon_oauth
SEC_CREDENTIAL_DIRECTORY_OAUTH = $(SEC_CREDENTIAL_DIRECTORY)/oauth
# The knob above will cause the Schedd to wait for $(SEC_CREDENTIAL_DIRECTORY_OAUTH)/CREDMON_COMPLETE
